summary: The National Republican Senatorial Committee claimed that Republicans do not wish to jail doctors for performing illegal abortions. However, many Republican-controlled states have enacted laws with severe penalties, including prison sentences for doctors who perform abortions illegally. For instance, Florida and Oklahoma have laws that could result in prison time for such actions, with Oklahoma imposing penalties of up to 10 years. Texas and Alabama have even harsher penalties, with potential life sentences on the table. Sen. Rick Scott and other Senate Republicans have supported federal legislation with similar penalties. PolitiFact rated the NRSC's claim as 'Pants on Fire', indicating that it is false.

title: Fact-check: Do Republicans want to throw doctors who break abortion ...
summary: A fact-check by PolitiFact examined the statement from the National Republican Senatorial Committee that Republicans do not want to imprison doctors for breaking abortion laws. The fact-check found this claim to be false ('Pants on Fire'). Multiple Republican-led states have enacted laws that include prison penalties for doctors performing illegal abortions. In Florida, violating abortion laws can lead to a maximum of five years in prison. In Oklahoma, penalties include up to 10 years in prison. Texas and Alabama have similar laws with harsh penalties, and many other Republican-controlled states have implemented or have the potential for such punitive measures. Additionally, several Republican senators co-sponsored federal legislation proposing up to five years in prison for certain abortion law violations. Despite these state laws and proposals, the National Republican Senatorial Committee did not provide evidence to support their claim.
snippet: In a memo to Republican candidates and lawmakers, the National Republican Senatorial Committee said that Republicans do not want to throw doctors in jail for violating abortion laws.

title: Transgender issues sharply divide Republicans, Democrats | Pew Research ...
summary: A Pew Research Center survey reveals a significant divide between Republicans and Democrats on transgender issues. While 54% of Americans believe gender is determined by birth-assigned sex, 44% believe it's possible to be a different gender. Eighty percent of Republicans hold the former view, while most Democrats (64%) hold the latter. Additionally, Democrats' opinions vary by education, race, and personal acquaintance with transgender individuals. Forty-three percent of Democrats know a transgender person, compared to 28% of Republicans. Society's acceptance of transgender people is also debated; 60% of Democrats feel it hasn't gone far enough, while 57% of Republicans believe it has gone too far. Millennials are the most likely to report knowing someone transgender.
snippet: Republicans, Democrats have starkly different views on transgender issues. The American public is fundamentally divided over whether its possible for someone to be a gender different from the sex they were assigned at birth, according to a new Pew Research Center survey.
